blue-headed-macaw
Macaws
Blue-Headed Macaw
/assets/img/parrots/blue-headed-macaw.webp
Also known as the Coulon's Macaw, this is a smaller, rare macaw. It is primarily green with a striking blue head, a patch of red under the tail, and a pale bill tipped in black.
16 inches (41 cm). Weight: 250-300g (8.8-10.5 oz)
Known to be intelligent, inquisitive, and generally gentler than other mini-macaws. They can be shy and reserved but are also playful and affectionate with their owners.
Moderate. Their call is higher-pitched and less grating than large macaws, making them a quieter option, though they can still be noisy.

<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="w-12 h-12 text-yellow-500" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="currentColor" aria-hidden="true" role="img" aria-label="Moderate"><title>Moderate</title><path d="M7 9v6h4l5 5V4l-5 5H7zm9.5 2.5c0 .75-.38 1.41-.97 1.82v-3.64c.59.41.97 1.07.97 1.82zM14 8.25v7.5c1.18-.41 2-1.57 2-2.75s-.82-2.34-2-2.75z"></path></svg>
Can learn a few words and phrases, but are not considered exceptional talkers. They are more known for their playful chirps and squawks.
A pelleted diet supplemented with fresh vegetables, fruits, and some nuts. They are known to enjoy foraging for food.
Can live for 30+ years. As they are rare in aviculture, specific health data is limited. A varied diet and regular vet check-ups are crucial. Prone to PDD like other macaws.
Being a mini-macaw, they require a cage of at least 30"W x 24"D x 48"H. Their moderate noise level could make them suitable for some apartment situations with tolerant neighbors.
Central & South America
src/content/species/blue-headed-macaw.json
4a3e896ca1a9fbc6
bare-eyed-cockatoo
Cockatoos
Bare-Eyed Cockatoo
/assets/img/parrots/bare-eyed-cockatoo.webp
A medium-sized white cockatoo, also known as a Little Corella, with a distinctive bare, greyish-blue patch of skin around its eyes. They are known for their playful and comical nature.
Extremely playful, intelligent, and outgoing. They can be very affectionate and are known for being clowns. They are also less prone to the high-strung nature of larger cockatoos.
Loud. While maybe not as deafening as a Moluccan, they have a very loud call and enjoy using it, especially in the morning and evening.
Can be very good talkers, with a clear ability to mimic words and phrases. They are also very vocal with a variety of squawks and calls.
A high-quality pelleted diet should form the base. Supplement with fresh vegetables, some fruit, and limited nuts. They are prone to obesity.
A hardy species with a lifespan of 50+ years. Prone to PBFD and fatty liver disease if on an improper diet. Their playful nature requires a lot of enriching toys.
Can be challenging for apartments due to their noise level. They need a very durable cage with a strong lock, as they are clever escape artists. Minimum size: 36"W x 24"D x 48"H.
Australia & Oceania
src/content/species/bare-eyed-cockatoo.json
black-capped-lory
Lories & Lorikeets
Black-capped Lory
/assets/img/parrots/black-capped-lory.webp
A beautiful lory with a black cap, a vibrant red neck and chest, blue belly, and green wings. They are a sight to behold.
12 inches (30.5 cm). Weight: 200-240g (7-8.5 oz)
Intelligent, active, and can be quite demanding of attention. They can be nippy and require an owner who can provide firm, consistent training.
Loud. They have a shrill, piercing whistle and can be quite vocal throughout the day.
Fair talkers. They can learn words and phrases but are better known for their loud whistles and ability to mimic sounds.
Must be fed a nectar-based diet. Commercial lory formulas are readily available. Soft fruits and edible flowers can be offered as treats.

Can live for 25+ years. Their liquid, sugary diet means their cages must be cleaned daily to prevent bacterial and fungal growth. They are prone to stress-related illnesses if not given enough attention.
Not a good choice for apartments due to their high noise level and mess. They require a large cage for their active lifestyle, minimum 36"W x 24"D x 24"H.
src/content/species/black-capped-lory.json
blue-fronted-amazon
Amazons
Blue-fronted Amazon
/assets/img/parrots/blue-fronted-amazon.webp
A popular Amazon species, characterized by a patch of blue or turquoise on their forehead. The amount of blue varies greatly between individuals.
Playful, intelligent, and can be very affectionate. They are known for being relatively 'mellow' for an Amazon but can still be stubborn and strong-willed.
Loud. While maybe not as intense as the Yellow-naped, they can and will scream to get attention or express excitement.
Very good talkers and can mimic a wide range of sounds. They have clear, human-like voices.
An obesity-prone species. Their diet should consist of pellets, a wide array of fresh vegetables, and very limited high-sugar fruits and high-fat nuts.
Can live 50-80 years with proper care. Keep an eye on weight gain. Also susceptible to respiratory infections and sinus problems if not kept in a clean environment.
Requires a large space. A minimum cage size of 36"W x 24"D x 48"H is recommended. Not a good choice for apartment dwellers due to noise.
src/content/species/blue-fronted-amazon.json
blue-and-gold-macaw
Blue and Gold Macaw
/assets/img/parrots/blue-and-gold-macaw.webp
A large and iconic macaw with a brilliant blue back and wings, a golden-yellow chest and belly, and a white facial patch with lines of small black feathers.
Highly intelligent, social, and can form very strong bonds with their owners. They are playful and enjoy being the center of attention, but require consistent training to prevent nipping.
Very Loud. Their call is a powerful, harsh screech that can be heard from a long distance. They will use it to communicate and get attention.
Excellent talkers with the ability to learn a large vocabulary of words and phrases. Their voices are typically very clear.
Require a diet higher in fat than many other parrots. A high-quality pelleted diet should be supplemented with a variety of nuts (like walnuts, macadamias, and almonds), fresh fruits, and vegetables.
Can live 60-80+ years. Prone to feather plucking if bored or stressed, Proventricular Dilatation Disease (PDD), and overgrown beaks. They need plenty of hard toys to chew.
Requires a very large and durable cage, at least 48"W x 36"D x 72"H. An outdoor aviary is ideal. Absolutely not suitable for apartments due to their size and noise level.
src/content/species/blue-and-gold-macaw.json
black-headed-caique
Caiques
Black-headed Caique
/assets/img/parrots/black-headed-caique.webp
A small, stocky parrot with a black head, white throat and chest, yellow thighs, and green wings. They are often described as clowns.
9 inches (23 cm). Weight: 150-170g (5.3-6 oz)
Extremely playful, energetic, and comical. They love to hop, dance, and wrestle with toys. Can be nippy and require consistent training.
Moderate to Loud. Not as piercing as larger parrots, but they have a high-pitched, sharp call that can be frequent.
Not known for talking ability. They are more likely to learn whistles, beeps, and other environmental sounds.
High-energy birds that do well on a diet of pellets, fresh fruits, vegetables, and flowers. They can be picky eaters.
Generally hardy birds that can live 20-30 years. Ensure they have plenty of toys for chewing and energy-burning to prevent behavioral issues.
Suitable for apartments with tolerant neighbors. They are active and need a spacious cage for their size, at least 24"W x 24"D x 30"H, with lots of toys and room to hop.
src/content/species/black-headed-caique.json
5aa979a6ea0ffef5
bourkes-parakeet
Parakeets
Bourke's Parakeet
/assets/img/parrots/bourkes-parakeet.webp
A small, gentle parakeet with brownish-tinged plumage, a pinkish belly, and blue highlights on the wings and tail. They are known for their calm demeanor.
Very calm, quiet, and sweet-natured. They are not as active or demanding as budgies and are most active at dawn and dusk.
Very Quiet. They have a soft, melodious twittering call, making them one of the best choices for those who want a quiet bird.

<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" class="w-12 h-12 text-green-500" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="currentColor" aria-hidden="true" role="img" aria-label="Quiet"><title>Quiet</title><path d="M7 9v6h4l5 5V4l-5 5H7z"></path></svg>
Not known to talk. Their vocalizations are limited to soft, pleasant chirps and whistles.
A good-quality parakeet mix, pellets, fresh vegetables, fruits, and sprouted seeds. Enjoy ground foraging and grass seeds.
Generally hardy and can live 15-25 years. Less prone to behavioral issues due to their calm nature. Need a temperature range of 60-85°F.
Perfect for apartments. Their quiet nature is a huge plus. A cage that is longer than it is tall is ideal, minimum 24"L x 16"D x 16"H.
src/content/species/bourkes-parakeet.json
brown-headed-parrot
African Parrots
Brown-headed Parrot
/assets/img/parrots/brown-headed-parrot.webp
A small, stocky parrot that is primarily green, with a brownish-grey head and bright yellow feathers under the wings, which are visible during flight.
9 inches (23 cm). Weight: 120-140g (4.2-4.9 oz)
Generally shy, quiet, and sweet-natured. They are less demanding than many other Poicephalus parrots and can be very affectionate once they form a bond.
Quiet. Considered one of the quietest Poicephalus species, they tend to communicate with soft whistles and chirps.
Not known for their talking ability, but they can mimic a variety of household sounds. Their natural calls are not overly loud.
A high-quality pelleted diet, supplemented with fresh vegetables, leafy greens, and a small amount of fruit.
Generally a hardy species with a lifespan of 20-30 years. As with other Poicephalus, they can be susceptible to aspergillosis if kept in a damp or poorly ventilated environment.
Excellent for apartments due to their quiet nature. A minimum cage size of 24"W x 18"D x 24"H is suitable.
Africa
src/content/species/brown-headed-parrot.json
blue-headed-pionus
Pionus
Blue-Headed Pionus
/assets/img/parrots/blue-headed-pionus.webp
A stocky, medium-sized parrot with a brilliant blue head and neck, a green body, and red feathers under its tail. They have a distinctive bare white eye-ring.
11 inches (28 cm). Weight: 230-295g (8.1-10.4 oz)
Known for being exceptionally calm, quiet, and gentle. They are less demanding than many other parrots and make excellent, easy-going companions.
Low to moderate. Much quieter than Amazons or Macaws, making them very suitable for apartments.
Generally not known for their talking ability, though some individuals may learn a few words. They make soft, wheezing sounds when frightened, which is normal for the species.
A high-quality pelleted diet, supplemented with fresh vegetables and fruits. They are less prone to obesity than Amazons.
Generally healthy and hardy, with a lifespan of 25-40 years. Can be prone to aspergillosis and vitamin A deficiency.
A medium-large cage with a minimum size of 24"W x 24"D x 36"H is appropriate. They enjoy toys but are not as destructive as other parrots.
src/content/species/blue-headed-pionus.json
blue-throated-macaw
Blue-Throated Macaw
/assets/img/parrots/blue-throated-macaw.webp
A critically endangered macaw that is often mistaken for the Blue and Gold. They have a brilliant turquoise-blue throat, nape, and crown, contrasting with a golden-yellow underside.
Known for being intelligent, gentle, and inquisitive. They are less demanding and aggressive than many other large macaws, making them prized companions.
Loud. They have a loud macaw call, but it's generally considered to be less harsh and frequent than that of a Blue and Gold or Scarlet Macaw.
Good talkers, able to mimic a variety of words and phrases with clarity. They are also known for their playful, chattering sounds.
A formulated diet supplemented with fruits, vegetables, and a variety of nuts, particularly palm nuts, which are a favorite.
Can live for 50+ years. Being critically endangered, they require specialized care. They are susceptible to PDD and require a very clean environment. Regular veterinary care is essential.
Needs a very large cage or aviary, minimum 48"W x 36"D x 60"H. Not suitable for apartments.
src/content/species/blue-throated-macaw.json
cfb5986d2fedfc05
budgerigar-budgie
Budgerigar (Budgie)
/assets/img/parrots/budgerigar-budgie.webp
One of the most popular pets in the world, the budgie is a small, long-tailed, seed-eating parrot. Wild budgies are green and yellow, but selective breeding has produced a rainbow of colors.
7-8 inches (18-20 cm). Weight: 30-40g (1-1.4 oz)
Social, cheerful, and energetic. They are intelligent little birds that are relatively easy to tame and can become very affectionate with their owners.
Quiet. Their chatter is generally pleasant and not disruptive, making them ideal for almost any living situation.
Can be excellent talkers, with some males learning hundreds of words. Their voices are fast and high-pitched. Both sexes are great at whistling and chattering.
A high-quality pelleted diet should form the base. Supplement with a variety of fresh vegetables (leafy greens, shredded carrots) and a small amount of fruit. Seed should be a treat, not a staple.
Can live 5-15 years. Prone to tumors, liver problems (often diet-related), and scaly mites on the beak and feet. A clean cage and a healthy diet are crucial.
Perfect for apartments. They are small and quiet. A cage that is wider than it is tall is best, with a minimum size of 18"W x 18"D x 18"H, but bigger is always better.
src/content/species/budgerigar-budgie.json
f7c2aeda33adeb34
buffons-macaw
Buffon's Macaw
/assets/img/parrots/buffons-macaw.webp
Also known as the Great Green Macaw, it is the second-largest macaw species. It is primarily yellowish-green with a red forehead, blue on the lower back, and an orange and blue tail.
Gentle, intelligent, and social. They are often described as being calmer than the Scarlet or Military Macaw, but still require significant attention and interaction.
Very Loud. They have an extremely powerful call that is deep and resonant.
Fair talkers, but are not known for extensive vocabularies. They are more likely to learn loud, natural calls and sounds.
Requires a diet with a good balance of pellets, fresh fruits, vegetables, and nuts. They have a particular fondness for certain types of seeds and nuts.
Can live for 60-70 years. Endangered in the wild. Susceptible to PDD and Pacheco's disease. Their large, powerful beak requires an abundance of tough, safe chew toys.
Requires an exceptionally large and robust cage or aviary. A minimum of 48"W x 36"D x 72"H is necessary. Unsuitable for apartments.
src/content/species/buffons-macaw.json
citron-crested-cockatoo
Citron-Crested Cockatoo
/assets/img/parrots/citron-crested-cockatoo.webp
A subspecies of the Lesser Sulphur-Crested Cockatoo, the Citron is distinguished by its brilliant orange crest and orange patches on its cheeks. They are otherwise white.
Intelligent, inquisitive, and playful. They can be slightly quieter and more reserved than other Sulphur-Crested subspecies, but still require a huge amount of social interaction.
Very Loud. Possess the classic, ear-splitting cockatoo screech, especially when excited or demanding attention.
Fair talkers. They can learn a number of words and phrases but are more known for their loud screams.
A low-fat pelleted diet is crucial to prevent obesity. Supplement with a wide variety of vegetables and very limited fruit.
Can live for 40-50 years. Prone to feather plucking, PBFD, and fatty liver disease. They are known to produce a lot of feather dust.
Not suitable for apartments. They need a strong, durable cage with plenty of toys. Minimum size: 30"W x 24"D x 48"H.
src/content/species/citron-crested-cockatoo.json
79e396bc21cdc8a7
cape-parrot
Cape Parrot
/assets/img/parrots/cape-parrot.webp
A large, robust parrot from the Poicephalus genus, the Cape Parrot is mostly green with an olive-yellow to brownish head. Females often have a distinct orange-red patch on their forehead.
13 inches (33 cm). Weight: 300-400g (10.5-14 oz)
Highly intelligent, playful, and can be very affectionate. They are known for their somewhat demanding nature and can become 'one-person' birds if not well-socialized.
Moderate to Loud. They have a powerful call and can be quite vocal, especially during the morning and evening.
Good talkers with the ability to develop a clear vocabulary of words and phrases.

Requires a specialized diet as they are adapted to eating nuts from specific trees. A formulated pellet diet supplemented with a variety of vegetables and nuts is recommended. Consult an avian vet for specifics.
Susceptible to Psittacine Beak and Feather Disease (PBFD). Their large, powerful beaks require plenty of hard, durable toys to keep them healthy and trim. Can live for 30+ years.
Needs a very large and extremely durable cage due to their powerful beak. A minimum of 36"W x 24"D x 48"H is recommended. Their potential noise makes them unsuitable for most apartments.
src/content/species/cape-parrot.json
cockatiel
Cockatiel
/assets/img/parrots/cockatiel.webp
Distinctive crested parrots from Australia. Grey body with white wing patches, orange cheek circles, and yellow head (males). Many color mutations exist including lutino, pied, and pearl varieties.
Gentle, affectionate, and social. Generally calm and less demanding than larger parrots. Males tend to be more vocal and outgoing than females.
Moderate. They whistle, chirp, and can be vocal especially at dawn and dusk. Not as loud as larger parrots but can be persistent.
Males are excellent whistlers and can learn songs and simple words. They often mimic household sounds. Females are generally quieter but can learn some vocalizations.
High-quality cockatiel pellets as base diet, supplemented with fresh vegetables, fruits, and some seeds. Provide cuttlebone for calcium and mineral block.

Generally healthy and can live 15-25 years. Prone to night frights, fatty liver disease, and egg-binding in females. Need UV light exposure, regular nail trims, and spacious caging. Watch for signs of illness as they hide symptoms well.
Minimum 24" x 18" x 24" cage. Bar spacing 1/2 to 5/8 inch. Provide multiple perches, toys, and climbing opportunities. Need 10-12 hours quiet darkness for sleep.
src/content/species/cockatiel.json
chattering-lory
Chattering Lory
/assets/img/parrots/chattering-lory.webp
A stunning, mostly red lory with green wings, a patch of yellow on its back, and a bright orange beak. They are known for their very talkative nature.
12 inches (30.5 cm). Weight: 170-200g (6-7 oz)
Outgoing, playful, and very affectionate. They are highly social birds that thrive on interaction and can become very cuddly with their owners.
Very Loud. True to their name, they chatter constantly and also have a loud, ringing call.
Excellent talkers. They are among the best talking lories and can develop a large vocabulary of words and phrases, mixed in with their constant chattering.
Requires a commercial nectar formula as the base of their diet. This should be supplemented with fresh, soft fruits like papaya and mango, and edible flowers.
Can live for 20-30 years. Like all lories, their droppings are liquid and messy. They need constant mental stimulation to prevent boredom and related stress behaviors.
Not suitable for apartments due to their very high noise level. They need a large, active cage, minimum 36"W x 24"D x 30"H.
src/content/species/chattering-lory.json
double-yellow-headed-amazon
Double Yellow-headed Amazon
/assets/img/parrots/double-yellow-headed-amazon.webp
A large, popular Amazon known for its striking yellow head, which spreads down the neck as it matures. They are highly sought after for their talking and singing ability.
Highly intelligent, social, and confident. Can be very affectionate but are prone to bonding strongly with one person and can become aggressive, especially during breeding season.
Very Loud. Possess an extremely powerful voice and are not shy about using it.
Among the best talkers in the parrot world, capable of amazing clarity and extensive vocabularies. They are also talented singers.
Prone to obesity. A low-fat pelleted diet is crucial, supplemented with a wide variety of vegetables. Fruit and nuts should be given sparingly.
Can live for 60+ years. Susceptible to obesity, fatty liver disease, atherosclerosis, and upper respiratory infections.
Needs a very large and durable cage due to their size and beak strength. Not suitable for apartments. Minimum cage: 40"W x 30"D x 60"H.
src/content/species/double-yellow-headed-amazon.json
congo-african-grey
Congo African Grey
/assets/img/parrots/congo-african-grey.webp
The Congo African Grey is the larger of the two common subspecies, with silvery-grey feathers, a white mask around the eyes, and a bright red tail. They have a solid black beak.
Extremely intelligent, highly sensitive, and can form very strong bonds with their owners. They can be prone to anxiety and stress if not properly stimulated.
Moderate to Loud. Can develop loud screams, especially if seeking attention.
Renowned for their exceptional ability to mimic human speech and sounds with incredible clarity.
A balanced diet of high-quality pellets, fresh vegetables (especially those high in Vitamin A like sweet potatoes and kale), fruits, and a limited amount of nuts.
Can live for 50-80 years. Susceptible to feather-picking, psittacosis, and hypocalcemia (low calcium levels). Regular mental stimulation is crucial for their well-being.
Requires a large space. A cage of at least 40"W x 30"D x 60"H is suitable. Their potential for loud calls makes them a challenge for apartment living.
src/content/species/congo-african-grey.json
ducorps-cockatoo
Ducorps’ Cockatoo
/assets/img/parrots/ducorps-cockatoo.webp
A medium-sized, all-white cockatoo with a small recumbent crest and a pale blue eye-ring. They are known for being more gentle and less demanding than other cockatoos.
Playful, gentle, and relatively quiet for a cockatoo. They are known to be very friendly and less prone to biting or neurotic behaviors than many of their cousins.
Moderate to Loud. While quieter than the large cockatoos, they can still produce a loud screech when they want to.
Not known for their talking ability, but they are intelligent and can learn some words. Their calls are generally less harsh than other cockatoos.
A balanced diet of pellets, fresh vegetables, and some fruit. They are active birds and can be good eaters.
Generally a hardy species with a lifespan of 40+ years. They still produce feather dust and need regular bathing. PBFD is a concern for all cockatoos.
May be suitable for some apartment situations due to their more moderate noise level. They are active and need a spacious cage, minimum 30"W x 22"D x 40"H.
src/content/species/ducorps-cockatoo.json
dusky-conure
Conures
Dusky Conure
/assets/img/parrots/dusky-conure.webp
A medium-sized conure with more subdued coloring, featuring a dusky or greyish-brown head and breast that blends into an olive-green body. They are known for their sweet nature.
Gentle, affectionate, and relatively quiet for a conure. They are known to be less nippy and demanding than some of their more colorful cousins, making them great companions.
Moderate. While capable of loud calls, they are generally considered to be one of the quieter Aratinga conures.
Can learn a few words, but are not known for being prolific talkers. Their vocalizations are often a series of pleasant chirps and squawks.
A balanced diet of high-quality pellets, supplemented with a variety of fresh vegetables, leafy greens, and a small amount of fruit.
A hardy species with a lifespan of 20+ years. Like other conures, they can be susceptible to PBFD and Pacheco's disease. Ensure they have plenty of toys for mental stimulation.
Their moderate noise level can make them suitable for apartment living with tolerant neighbors. A cage of at least 24"W x 20"D x 30"H is recommended.
src/content/species/dusky-conure.json
dusky-lory
Dusky Lory
/assets/img/parrots/dusky-lory.webp

A uniquely colored lory with two main color phases: one with a brownish-black body with a bright orange or yellow bib, and another that is more olive-green. Both have striking orange and red markings.
10 inches (25.5 cm). Weight: 90-115g (3.2-4 oz)
Playful, intelligent, and curious. They are known for their comical antics and can be quite affectionate. They are very active and enjoy swinging and playing with toys.
Moderate to Loud. They have a high-pitched, repetitive call that can be noisy, but they are generally not as loud as a Rainbow or Chattering Lory.
Can learn to mimic a good number of words and sounds. Their voice is high-pitched and they enjoy chattering.
A liquid nectar diet is essential. Commercially prepared formulas are best. Supplement with a variety of soft fruits and some vegetables.
Can live 20+ years. Messy droppings are a given. Prone to fungal infections if their environment is not kept scrupulously clean. They need a lot of toys to keep them occupied.
Can be manageable in an apartment if the owner is diligent about cleaning and can tolerate moderate noise. A cage of at least 30"W x 24"D x 24"H is needed.
src/content/species/dusky-lory.json
9e7f393eb183bbc9
eclectus-parrot
Eclectus
Eclectus Parrot
/assets/img/parrots/eclectus-parrot.webp
A medium-large parrot with extreme sexual dimorphism. Males are a brilliant emerald green with a candy-corn colored beak, while females are a stunning combination of bright red and royal blue/purple.
Generally calm, gentle, and intelligent. They are less prone to screaming than Amazons or Cockatoos. Females tend to be more dominant and territorial than the more easy-going males.
Moderate. Much quieter than most large parrots, making them suitable for many home environments. They have a range of calls, but are not constant screamers.
Good talking ability with clear, pleasant voices. Both sexes can learn words and phrases, and can be quite chatty, though individuals vary.
A specialized diet with a heavy emphasis on fresh fruits and vegetables is crucial. They have a longer digestive tract and cannot handle many artificial ingredients or fortified pellets.
Can live 30-50+ years. Prone to toe-tapping and wing-flipping if their diet is incorrect (too many vitamins/minerals). Sensitive to medications and artificial additives.
Large cage minimum 36"W x 24"D x 48". Bar spacing 3/4 to 1 inch. They are less destructive than many large parrots but still need plenty of toys.
src/content/species/eclectus-parrot.json
0248d9d8ea2b44ae
fischers-lovebird
Lovebirds
Fischer's Lovebird
/assets/img/parrots/fischers-lovebird.webp
A small, beautiful lovebird with a green body, golden-yellow neck, and a fiery orange-red face. A prominent white eye-ring gives them a distinct look.
5.5 inches (14 cm). Weight: 40-50g (1.4-1.8 oz)
Playful, charming, and social. They are known for being slightly less aggressive and territorial than Peach-faced Lovebirds, but still have big personalities.
Loud. They have a very high-pitched, shrill call that can be quite piercing.
Not known to mimic speech. Their main vocalization is their loud, natural call.
A balanced diet of small pellets, fresh vegetables, and a small amount of fruit is ideal. They enjoy a variety of greens.
Can live 15-20 years. Prone to eye infections if their environment isn't clean. Also susceptible to psittacosis and common avian bacterial infections.
Their loud call makes them a potential issue for apartments. They need a secure cage with small bar spacing. Minimum 20"W x 20"D x 24"H.
src/content/species/fischers-lovebird.json
gang-gang-cockatoo
Gang-Gang Cockatoo
/assets/img/parrots/gang-gang-cockatoo.webp
A unique, small cockatoo from Australia. They are sexually dimorphic: males are dark grey with a striking bright red head and wispy crest, while females are all grey.
Relatively quiet, gentle, and can be shy. They are not as cuddly as other cockatoos and are less common in aviculture due to their specialized needs.

Can learn a fair number of words, but are more known for their loud screams and playful chattering.
A high-quality pelleted diet, lots of fresh vegetables, and limited fruits and nuts to prevent weight gain.
Can live 60-80+ years. Extremely prone to feather plucking and self-mutilation if their social needs are not met. They also produce a large amount of powder down.
Not suitable for apartments. Requires a large, durable cage with plenty of toys. Minimum 40"W x 30"D x 60"H.

White-fronted Amazon
/assets/img/parrots/white-fronted-amazon.webp

The smallest of the Amazon parrots. They are mostly green with a white patch on the forehead, blue on the crown, and red around the eyes. They are sexually dimorphic; males have bright red feathers on their wings.
Active, playful, and can be feisty. They have a 'big parrot' personality in a small body and can be prone to nipping if not well-trained.
Moderate to Loud. Their call is high-pitched and can be quite yappy and repetitive.
Fair talkers. They can learn some words but are not known for extensive vocabularies.
A standard pelleted diet with fresh vegetables and some fruit. Their smaller size makes portion control important.
Generally hardy with a lifespan of 40-50 years, but can be prone to obesity if overfed and under-exercised.
A smaller cage is acceptable but should still be roomy. Minimum 24"W x 20"D x 30"H. Can be suitable for apartments if the owner can manage their sometimes yappy calls.

White-bellied Caique

Similar in build to the Black-headed Caique, but with a vibrant orange or yellow head, white belly, and green wings. They are equally energetic.
Goofy, fearless, and always on the move. They have a reputation for being slightly more high-strung than the Black-headed variety. Very cuddly on their own terms.
Moderate to Loud. Their calls can be very loud and shrill, especially when excited.
Limited talking ability. They are excellent mimics of sounds and can learn many whistles.
A varied diet is key. High-quality pellets, a good mix of fresh vegetables, and a bit more fruit than other parrots to match their high energy levels.
Can live 20-30 years. Polyomavirus can be a concern, so ensure they come from a reputable breeder. Prone to getting into trouble due to their fearless nature.
Can be suitable for apartments, but noise is a factor. A roomy cage is a must, 24"W x 24"D x 30"H at a minimum, to accommodate their acrobatic antics.

white-tailed-black-cockatoo
White-Tailed Black Cockatoo
/assets/img/parrots/white-tailed-black-cockatoo.webp
This common name refers to two endangered species from Western Australia: Baudin's and Carnaby's Black Cockatoos. They are large, black birds with white tail panels and white cheek patches.
Not kept as pets. They are endangered wild birds with highly specialized needs and behaviors. They are social birds that live in large flocks.
Very Loud. They have a distinctive, far-carrying call that sounds like 'wee-oo'.
Their vocalizations are their natural calls, which are important for flock communication.
Specialized diet consisting of native seeds, particularly from marri and banksia trees. Their habitat and food sources are under threat.
Lifespan of up to 50 years. Endangered species protected by law. They are not part of the pet trade and their health is a major conservation concern.
Not a pet species. They are wild birds that require large areas of native woodland to survive.

yellow-collared-macaw
Yellow-Collared Macaw
/assets/img/parrots/yellow-collared-macaw.webp
A popular mini-macaw, mostly green with a distinctive bright yellow band on the back of its neck that develops with age. They have a black forehead and a reddish belly patch.
15 inches (38 cm). Weight: 250-280g (8.8-9.9 oz)
Intelligent, curious, and mischievous. They are known for being very playful and can be affectionate, but they also have a stubborn streak and can be nippy.
Loud for their size. They have a high-pitched, piercing call that can be quite repetitive when they want something.
Very good talkers. They can develop a clear vocabulary of words and are known for their ability to learn tricks and mimic sounds.
A balanced diet consisting of high-quality pellets, fresh vegetables, leafy greens, and a limited amount of fruit and nuts.
Can live for 50+ years. A hardy species. Prone to feather plucking if bored. They need plenty of chewable toys to keep their beaks in good condition.
Needs a roomy cage, minimum 30"W x 24"D x 36"H. Their potential for noise makes them a challenging, but not impossible, choice for apartments.

yellow-crowned-amazon
Yellow-crowned Amazon
/assets/img/parrots/yellow-crowned-amazon.webp
A large green parrot with a distinct patch of yellow on the crown. They are often confused with the Yellow-naped and Double Yellow-headed Amazons.
Intelligent and playful. They are often considered to be a bit calmer and less prone to the intense aggression of the other two 'yellow head' types, but still require firm handling.
Loud. Can produce the classic loud Amazon screams.
Very good talkers, though perhaps slightly less gifted on average than the Yellow-naped and Double Yellow-headed.
A low-fat diet is crucial. Base the diet on pellets and a wide variety of vegetables.
Can live for 60+ years. Prone to obesity, fatty liver disease, and Vitamin A deficiency.
Needs a large, strong cage. Minimum 36"W x 24"D x 48"H. Unsuitable for apartments.

yellow-tailed-black-cockatoo
Yellow-Tailed Black Cockatoo
/assets/img/parrots/yellow-tailed-black-cockatoo.webp
A large black cockatoo from southeastern Australia, with distinctive yellow patches on its cheeks and yellow panels in its long tail. They have a crest that curls forward.
Generally gentle for a large parrot, but they are not common in aviculture. They are active, social birds with a very powerful beak.
Very Loud. They have a very loud, high-pitched, wailing call that can be heard from far away, often described as 'kee-ow'.
Not known for talking ability. Their vocalizations consist of their loud, natural calls.
A specialized diet consisting of seeds from native trees like banksia, hakea, and pine cones, as well as wood-boring grubs.
Can live for 60+ years. Rarely kept as pets and require a very experienced keeper. They need a huge amount of space and a specialized diet.
Requires a very large outdoor aviary with plenty of wood to destroy. Not suitable for an indoor or home environment.

yellow-naped-amazon
Yellow-naped Amazon
/assets/img/parrots/yellow-naped-amazon.webp
Known for their striking green plumage and a distinct yellow patch on the nape of the neck, which grows with age. They have a robust build and a powerful beak.
Highly intelligent, outgoing, and often comical. They can be prone to hormonal aggression ('bluffing') during adolescence and breeding season.
Very Loud. They have powerful voices and are known for their enthusiastic screaming sessions, especially in the morning and evening.
Exceptional talkers and singers. Many can develop extensive vocabularies and learn full songs.
Prone to obesity. Requires a diet low in fat, based on high-quality pellets, with a large variety of fresh vegetables and limited fruit and nuts.
Long-lived (50-80+ years) and require experienced handling. Vulnerable to obesity, fatty liver disease, and Vitamin A deficiency. Regular exercise is essential.
Needs a large space. A cage no smaller than 36"W x 24"D x 48"H is needed, but bigger is better. Unsuitable for apartments due to high noise levels.
